title: July 2014 Licensure Exam: Paper Four
description: Examination covering Mental Health, Community Health, Management, and Teaching methodology.

questions.question: The initial symptoms of lithium toxicity include:

options.text: Tremors, shuffling gait, and rigidity
Stiff neck, occipital headache and increased blood pressure
Ataxia, blurred vision and severe nausea
Fever, sore throat and cardiac arrhythmias

questions.explanation: Early signs of Lithium toxicity (levels > 1.5 mEq/L) typically involve the GI tract (severe nausea) and CNS (ataxia, blurred vision, coarse tremors).
questions.hint: Think of CNS and GI symptoms occurring together.

questions.question: In acute mania a patient presents with:

options.text: Cheerful and expansive mood
Excessive psychomotor activity
Increased motor activity
Organized thought content and process

questions.explanation: The hallmark of mania is an elevated, expansive, or irritable mood. While psychomotor activity is increased, the mood disturbance is the primary defining feature of the affect.
questions.hint: Focus on the primary alteration in 'affect' or mood.

questions.question: In helping a child with a gender identity problem the most appropriate nursing intervention is:

options.text: Give positive reinforcement when he/she engages in opposite sex behaviour
Give positive reinforcement when he/she engages in assigned sex behaviour
Do not allow the child to interact with others until he/she demonstrates only appropriate behaviour
Withdraw privileges if the child is noncompliant

questions.explanation: Behavioral modification approaches reinforce behaviors congruent with the child's assigned biological sex to reduce dysphoria. Punitive measures are inappropriate.
questions.hint: Think about positive reinforcement of the desired outcome.

questions.question: In narcissistic personality disorder there is a pervasive pattern of:

options.text: Social discomfort fear of negative evaluation and timidity
Grandiosity lack of empathy and hypersensitivity to evaluation by others
Dependence and submissive behaviour beginning by early adulthood
Indifference to social relationships and restricted range of emotional experience and expression

questions.explanation: Narcissistic Personality Disorder is characterized by a grandiose sense of self-importance, a need for admiration, and a lack of empathy.
questions.hint: Look for keywords like 'grandiosity' and 'lack of empathy'.

questions.question: The unipolar mood disorders include:

options.text: Cyclothymia and mixed manic episodes
Hypomania and dysthymia
Major depression and mixed manic states
Cyclothymia and mood disorders related to manic conditions
Major depression and dysthymia (implied best fit)

questions.explanation: Unipolar refers to depression only, without mania. Dysthymia and Major Depression are unipolar disorders. The provided options in the original paper were flawed as they mixed bipolar elements, but clinically, unipolar covers MDD and Dysthymia.
questions.hint: Unipolar means 'one pole' - typically the depressive pole, without mania.

questions.question: Micro-teaching is:

options.text: Real teaching focusing on developing pupil abilities
Composed of a scaled up class size, content and time
Mainly focused on training for the development of specific teaching skills
Not individualized but largely depends on group feedback

questions.explanation: Micro-teaching is a teacher training technique practicing a specific skill for a short time with a small group (scaled down).
questions.hint: It focuses on specific skills in a 'micro' environment.

questions.question: The steps of demonstrating a psychomotor skill are:

options.text: Formulate behaviour objectives, perform skill analysis, assess entry behaviour of learners and formulate a lesson plan
Formulate a lesson plan, perform skills analysis, assess learners entry behaviour and formulate behavioural objectives
Assess entry behaviour of learners, formulate lesson plan, formulate behavioural objectives and perform skills analysis
Perform skills analysis, formulate behavioral objectives, formulate lesson plan and assess the entry behaviours of learners

questions.explanation: Planning involves: Objectives -> Skill Analysis -> Entry Behavior Assessment -> Lesson Plan Formulation.
questions.hint: You must know what you want to achieve (objectives) and break down the skill (analysis) before assessing the audience.

questions.question: Objective questions:

options.text: Measure student’s proficiency in performing procedures
Activates several senses in a learner
Improves on student’s reflective thinking and skills on patient care
Measures student’s achievement in relation to knowledge, skills and attitudes

questions.explanation: Objective questions (like MCQs) efficiently sample a wide range of content to measure achievement, primarily in knowledge.
questions.hint: These questions are best for measuring 'achievement' or knowledge retention.

questions.question: A good report should be:

options.text: Written instantly, concise and clear
Contextualized, brief and enriched with the writers opinion
Free of extraneous materials, concise and complete
Promptly written, data enriched and to detail in all aspects

questions.explanation: A professional report should be factual, concise, complete, and free of extraneous (irrelevant) details and subjective opinions.
questions.hint: It should contain only what is necessary and nothing more (concise/free of extraneous).

questions.question: Brain storming as a teaching strategy:

options.text: Ensures all group members have put up their ideas
Encourages discovery of knowledge
It yields into convincing solutions in most of the cases
It usually ends in useful conclusions and solutions to problems

questions.explanation: Brainstorming stimulates creativity and free association, encouraging discovery. It prioritizes quantity of ideas over immediate quality or solutions.
questions.hint: This strategy is about generating new ideas and 'discovery'.

questions.question: Anonymity in research is aimed at:

options.text: Preventing disclosure of privileged information
Conferring protection to the source of information
Selectively disclosing information to specific individuals
Keeping names of respondents only known to the research supervisor

questions.explanation: Anonymity protects the source by ensuring data cannot be linked to the participant, even by the researcher.
questions.hint: It protects the person providing the data (the source).

questions.question: The problem statement in a research proposal should include:

options.text: The background of the study
An outline of the study objectives
The magnitude of the issue under study
The benefits the study shall contribute against challenges

questions.explanation: A problem statement must articulate the magnitude or severity of the issue to justify the need for the study.
questions.hint: It justifies 'why' the problem is big enough to study.

questions.question: The Hawthorne effect is as a result of:

options.text: A researcher lacking expertise to analyze data
Study subjects being aware they are participating in a study
Study tools being disclosed to non study subjects
Respondents not completing the interview schedule

questions.explanation: The Hawthorne effect is the alteration of behavior by subjects because they know they are being observed.
questions.hint: It happens when people know they are being watched.

questions.question: The study design that is appropriate in observing the behaviour changes of drug addicts under rehabilitation is:

options.text: Retrospective study design
Longitudinal study design
Prospective study design
Cross sectional design

questions.explanation: Longitudinal studies involve repeated observations over time, making them ideal for tracking changes (like behavior) during a process like rehabilitation.
questions.hint: Which design follows the same subjects over a long period?

questions.question: The most appropriate method of studying characteristics of wound healing would be:

options.text: Questionnaire
Participants observation
Pure observation
Context analysis

questions.explanation: Wound healing is a physical process best assessed through direct, pure observation using a checklist. The researcher does not participate.
questions.hint: You have to look at the wound directly.

questions.question: A convulsing one month old infant should be given:

options.text: Phenobarbitone 20 mg/kg im stat
Diazepam 0.3 mg/kg iv 4 hourly over 1 minute
Phenobarbitone 5mg/kg im stat
Diazepam 1 mg/kg per rectal stat

questions.explanation: For neonates and young infants (< 1 month), Phenobarbital is the first-line anticonvulsant. Loading dose is 20 mg/kg.
questions.hint: Phenobarbital is preferred over Diazepam for neonates.

questions.question: The immediate management for severe dehydration in a child with severe malnutrition according to IMCI strategy includes:

options.text: Infusion of half strength darrows in 5% dextrose 15 mls/kg iv in 1 hr
Infusion of 0.9% normal saline 20ml/kg in 1 hr
Transfusion of whole blood 40 ml/kg over 3hrs as soon as it is available
NGT feeding with Resomal 15ml/kg/hr for 10 hours

questions.explanation: In severe malnutrition (SAM), IV fluids are dangerous due to heart failure risk. Rehydration is done orally or via NGT using ReSoMal at a slow rate.
questions.hint: Avoid IV fluids in SAM unless there is shock; use the gut (NGT).

questions.question: The ratio of infant chest compressions to ventilation where rescue is involved is:
questions.explanation: For infants/children with two rescuers (healthcare setting), the ratio is 15:2. Single rescuer is 30:2.
questions.hint: Two rescuers for a child/infant use the 15:2 ratio.

questions.question: Which of the following statements are TRUE? (Select all that apply)

options.text: The iliac crest is the site of choice for bone marrow aspiration in a 5 year old child
Acute renal failure is the leading complication associated with acute Glomerulonephritis
The sternum is the site of choice for bone marrow aspiration in a 5 year old
Acute Glomerulonephritis rarely causes renal complications

questions.explanation: The posterior iliac crest is the preferred site for bone marrow aspiration in children > 2 years. ARF is a serious complication of AGN.
questions.hint: Both statements A and B from the original text are considered True.

questions.question: Haemophilus influenza type B (HIB) vaccine is given to protect against:

options.text: Diphtheria and whooping cough
Hepatitis B and whooping cough
Hepatitis B and meningitis
Meningitis and pneumonia

questions.explanation: HIB is a major cause of bacterial meningitis and pneumonia in children under 5 years.
questions.hint: HIB causes severe respiratory and CNS infections.

questions.question: List six (6) danger signs of a sick child. (Select all correct signs)

options.text: Inability to drink or breastfeed
Vomits everything
History of convulsions
Lethargic or unconscious
Chest indrawing
Mild fever

questions.explanation: IMCI Danger signs: Inability to drink, vomits everything, convulsions, lethargy/unconsciousness, chest indrawing, stridor.
questions.hint: Think of the IMCI general danger signs.

questions.question: Match the term with its correct definition:

pairs.right: Helping client explore problems and find own solutions
Treatment of mental disorders via psychological means

questions.explanation: Counseling facilitates self-solution; Guidance offers advice/direction; Psychotherapy treats disorders.
questions.hint: Guidance gives direction; Counseling empowers self-direction.

questions.question: Select the rules/responsibilities of a nurse in Milieu therapy.

options.text: Ensuring Safety (environment/aggression management)
Providing Structure (consistent schedule)
Facilitating Socialization
Isolating patients permanently

questions.explanation: Milieu therapy involves using the environment therapeutically: Safety, Structure, Socialization, and Support.
questions.hint: The environment itself is the therapy tool.

questions.question: Match the letter in the acronym 'SPICES' (innovative curriculum) to its meaning:
questions.explanation: SPICES: Student-centered, Problem-based, Integrated, Community-based, Electives, Systematic.
questions.hint: Think about modern medical education strategies.

questions.question: Order the first five stages of social change (Rogers' Innovation-Decision Process):
questions.explanation: Knowledge -> Persuasion -> Decision -> Implementation -> Confirmation.
questions.hint: You must know about it before you become interested or try it.

questions.question: Which of the following are clinical features of chronic otitis media?

options.text: Persistent purulent otorrhea (> 2 weeks)
Hearing loss (Conductive)
Tympanic membrane perforation
Usually painless
Severe acute ear pain

questions.explanation: Chronic OM presents with painless, persistent discharge and hearing loss. Acute pain suggests Acute OM.
questions.hint: Chronic usually means long-term discharge, often without acute pain.

questions.question: Arrange the phases of psychological debriefing (Mitchell Model) in order:
questions.explanation: Intro -> Facts -> Thoughts -> Reactions -> Symptoms -> Teaching -> Re-entry.
questions.hint: Starts with facts, moves to feelings/thoughts, then symptoms and teaching.

questions.question: Select the characteristics of good teaching aids.

options.text: Relevant to the topic
Accurate information
Visible/Audible to all
Simple and uncluttered
Expensive and complex

questions.explanation: Good aids are Relevant, Accurate, Visible, Simple, and Durable.
questions.hint: They must be easily seen and understood by the learners.

questions.question: What are the qualities of a good questionnaire?

options.text: Clear and unambiguous
Relevant to objectives
Concise/Brief
Objective/Unbiased
Lengthy and complicated

questions.explanation: Questionnaires should be Clear, Relevant, Brief, Unbiased, and Logically sequenced.
questions.hint: Think about what makes it easy for a respondent to answer.

questions.question: Case Study: Mrs. X (35yo) admitted with Schizophrenia. Select correct management steps.

richContent.content:
Patient: Mrs. X, 35 years old, single mother of 4.

Diagnosis: Schizophrenia.

options.text: Pharmacotherapy: Antipsychotics (e.g., Haloperidol)
Therapeutic Relationship: Establish trust and consistency
Managing Delusions: Acknowledge feelings but present reality gently
Reinforce delusions to keep patient calm
Family therapy to support the single mother context

questions.explanation: Management involves meds, safety, therapeutic communication (present reality, don't reinforce delusions), and social support.
questions.hint: Do not argue with delusions, but do not reinforce them.

questions.question: Case Study: Master K (10yo) with Rheumatic Fever. Select correct diagnostic investigations and management.

richContent.content:
Patient: Master K, 10 years old.

Diagnosis: Rheumatic Fever.

options.text: Investigation: ASO Titer (Anti-Streptolysin O)
Investigation: Throat Swab Culture
Management: Penicillin therapy (eradication & prophylaxis)
Management: Bed rest during acute phase
Management: Early ambulation and exercise

questions.explanation: Diagnosis relies on evidence of Strep infection (ASO, culture). Management prioritizes bed rest (to save the heart) and Penicillin.
questions.hint: Bed rest is crucial to prevent cardiac damage.
